content.webTitle: EDF's direct debit glitch highlights supplier's right to charge

fields.headline: EDF's direct debit glitch highlights supplier's right to charge
fields.bodyText: I arranged to pay my energy bills by direct debit in April 2011 and received a letter confirming this. However, neither EDF nor I realised it had failed to set up the debits properly until two months ago, and it now reckons I owe it £1,514. Can the company bill me for 12 months like that when the direct debit failure was its responsibility? CB, Bletchley, Bedfordshire I'm sorry to tell you that you can be billed up to six years after a transaction. What is extraordinary about this is that EDF didn't notice it wasn't getting its dues from you and you, as you admit, were lax in not checking your bank statements more carefully. The company has now decided to cancel all the bills from before last November and to pay £100 in goodwill, so you now owe £746.74, which you can pay in monthly instalments over two years. So, stressful as the episode was, the error has ended up in your favour. If you need help email Anna Tims at your.problems@observer.co.uk or write to Your Problems, The Observer, Kings Place, 90 York Way, London N1 9GU. Please include an address and phone number.
